q: What is MCADD?
a: MCADD is a rare genetic condition where the body has difficulty breaking down fat for energy, leading to a build-up of harmful substances. It is usually detected through newborn blood spot testing.

q: Is MCADD a serious condition?
a: MCADD can be potentially serious if not recognized and treated quickly. However, with proper care, individuals with MCADD can live a normal and active life.

q: What are the symptoms of MCADD?
a: Babies with MCADD may experience symptoms such as irritability, poor feeding, sleepiness, floppiness, breathing difficulties, vomiting, seizures, and coma. In case of illness or poor feeding, they should be given a special high-sugar drink called glucose polymer.

q: What causes MCADD?
a: MCADD is caused by a genetic fault that affects the production of an enzyme called medium-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase (MCAD). This fault prevents complete breakdown of fat for energy, leading to harmful substances building up in the body.

q: How is MCADD inherited?
a: A child will only have MCADD if they inherit a copy of the faulty gene from both parents. The parents, who are carriers of the faulty gene, usually do not have the condition themselves.

q: How is MCADD screened and tested?
a: In England, a newborn blood spot test is offered to detect MCADD. Drops of blood are collected from the baby's heel and tested for abnormalities. Further tests may be carried out if a screen positive result is found.

q: What is the treatment for MCADD?
a: There is no specific treatment for MCADD. A specialist care team will provide advice on how to manage the condition, including a normal diet and the use of special high-sugar drinks when the individual is ill.

q: Can you tell me more about the National Congenital Anomaly and Rare Disease Registration Service?
a: The National Congenital Anomaly and Rare Disease Registration Service (NCARDRS) collects information to improve prevention and treatment of conditions like MCADD. You can choose to opt out of the register if desired.

q: Are there any support groups for MCADD?
a: Yes, there are support groups available, such as Metabolic Support UK. They provide information and support for individuals with MCADD and their families.

a: Babies with MCADD are at risk of developing symptoms such as irritability, poor feeding, sleepiness, floppiness, breathing difficulties, vomiting, seizures, and coma. It's important to give the emergency regimen if your baby is ill or not feeding well.

a: MCADD is caused by a fault in the gene that provides the instructions to make an enzyme called medium-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase (MCAD). This can lead to a lack of energy and a build-up of harmful substances in the body.

q: How is MCADD inherited?
a: A child will only be born with MCADD if they inherit a copy of the faulty gene that causes it from both of their parents. Most parents are carriers of the faulty gene but do not have the condition themselves.

q: How is MCADD screened and tested?
a: A newborn blood spot test is offered to all babies in England to detect problems including MCADD. Further urine and blood tests may be carried out if a screen positive result is found.

q: What are the treatment options for MCADD?
a: There's no specific treatment for MCADD. A specialist care team will provide advice on how to look after your child and support them as they get older. They may recommend a normal diet with special high-sugar drinks during illness.

q: Can someone with MCADD lead a normal life?
a: With proper care, there's no reason why someone with MCADD cannot live a normal, healthy, and active life.

q: Where can I find more information about MCADD?
a: You can find more information about MCADD from support groups like Metabolic Support UK. They provide information and support for people with MCADD and their families.

q: What is the emergency regimen for MCADD?
a: If your baby is ill or not feeding well, they should be given a special high-sugar drink known as glucose polymer. This is called the emergency regimen and can help manage the condition.

q: Is MCADD a lifelong condition?
a: Yes, MCADD is a lifelong condition that's present from birth. It is usually picked up through newborn screening tests.

q: What is MCADD?
a: MCADD is a rare genetic condition where a person has problems breaking down fat to use as an energy source. This can lead to a lack of energy and a build-up of harmful substances in the body.

q: How serious is MCADD?
i: MCADD is a potentially serious condition that can be life-threatening if not recognised quickly and treated appropriately. However, with proper care, there's no reason why someone with MCADD cannot live a normal, healthy, and active life.

q: What are the symptoms of MCADD?
a: Babies with MCADD are at risk of developing symptoms such as irritability, poor feeding, sleepiness, floppiness, breathing difficulties, vomiting, seizures (fits), and coma. If your baby is ill or not feeding well, they should be given a special high-sugar drink called glucose polymer.

q: What causes MCADD?
a: MCADD is caused by a fault in the gene that provides the instructions to make an enzyme called medium-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase (MCAD). This fault causes the enzyme to either not work properly or be missing entirely, which impairs the body's ability to break down fat for energy.

q: How is MCADD inherited?
a: A child will only be born with MCADD if they inherit a copy of the faulty gene from both of their parents. The parents themselves are usually carriers of the faulty gene but do not have the condition.

q: How is MCADD screened and tested?
a: A newborn blood spot test is offered to all babies in England to detect problems including MCADD. If a problem is found, further urine and blood tests will be carried out to confirm the diagnosis. Parents may also be tested to see if they carry the faulty gene.

q: How is MCADD treated?
a: There's no specific treatment for MCADD, but a specialist care team will provide advice and support. Regular follow-up appointments will be arranged, and special high-sugar drinks will be recommended for when the person is ill. It is important to avoid long periods without eating.

q: Where can I find support for MCADD?
a: You can find support through national or local support groups, such as Metabolic Support UK. They provide information about MCADD on their website and offer free support through Family Advisers.

q: Can MCADD be prevented?
a: MCADD cannot be prevented, but early detection through newborn screening and proper management can help individuals live a normal, healthy life.

q: What should I do if my child shows symptoms of MCADD?
a: If your child shows symptoms of MCADD, such as poor feeding or breathing difficulties, you should give them a special high-sugar drink called glucose polymer. If there is no improvement, you should take your child to the nearest A&E department immediately.
